questions.text: The ring shown in the image below is a ______________
questions.solution:
NuvaRing (as shown in the image above) is a hormonal contraceptive that releases ethinyl estradiol and etonogestrel once inserted into the vagina. The hormones are absorbed through the vaginal epithelium.

The ring is inserted within 5 days of onset of menses and is removed after 3 weeks to allow withdrawal bleeding. After removal, a new ring can be inserted in a week.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills
Combined pills(COC)

MALA-D(Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg+EE 0.03 mg+Ferrous Fumarate) 

MALA-N(Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg+EE 0.03 mg+ferrous fumarate) Govt supply. Free of cost. 
Progesterone only pills(POP)

Low dosage of progesterone, mainly norethisterone and levonorgestrel

Suitable for lactating women
Once a month(long-acting) pills

Long-acting oestrogen(quinestrol)+ short-acting progesterone

Highly disappointing results
Male pills(Gossypol)

Cottonseed derivative

Causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia

Post-coital pills (Interceptive)

 		 Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg tablet within 72 hrs and same dose after 12 hrs OR 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hrs
RU 486(Mifepristone) doses ranging from 10-600mg.
Ulipristal(30 mg) within 5 days
Centchroman: 2 tabs(60 mg) within 24 hrs
 GnRH agonists
CuT IUCD: inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

Progesterone only injectables

 

DMPA: 150 mg IM every 3 months

NET-EN: 200 mg IM every 2 months 

Combined injectables

  

Cyclofem: 25 mg DMPA+5 mg estradiol cypionate

Mesigyna: 50 mg NET-EN+5 mg estradiol valerate 

 

Subdermal implants

Norplant I

35 mg levonorgestrel

Norplant II/Jadelle

Two rods with 70 mg levonorgestrel each and a release rate of 50 mcg/day

Others

Hormonal IUCD

Mirena: 52 mg of LNG with release rate of approx. 20 mcg/day

The patch (ORTHOEVRA)

Norelgestomin+Ethinyl estradiol: Weekly for 3 weeks then patch free 1 week

Vaginal ring (NUVARING)

Etonogestrel+ethinyl estradiol daily release. Use for 3 weeks with a withdrawal week.

questions.text: Regarding palatoprints, all are true except?

choices.text: Palatal rugae are unique to each person
Palatoprints are located in posterior part of palate
Palatoprints do not change during growth

questions.solution:
Anterior part of the palate has rough raised ridges known as Palatoprints or palatal rugae.

Palatal rugae are irregular, asymmetric ridges of mucous membranes on the palate which are unique to each person and hence used as a method of identification.

Once formed, they do not undergo any changes during growth, remaining in the same position throughout a person's entire life.

The study of palatal rugae to establish identity is known as Rugoscopy/ Palatoscopy/ Palatoprints.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who met with a road traffic accident is brought to the casualty in an unconscious state. On eye examination, the right pupil is constricted, whereas the left pupil is dilated and unresponsive to light. A CT scan reveals left subdural hematoma. What is the ocular sign called?
questions.solution:
Hutchinson's pupil is seen in raised intracranial pressure (ICP) secondary to space-occupying lesions. The raised ICP compresses the oculomotor nerve and causes pupillary changes. The pupil on the side of the space-occupying lesion is affected first. The changes progress through three stages.

Stage Ipsilateral pupil Mechanism Opposite pupil Mechanism
1 Constricted Oculomotor nerve irritation Normal -
2 Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis Constricted Oculomotor nerve irritation
3 Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis  Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis 

Stage 3 indicates that the ICP is very high. Immediate cerebral decompression should be done in such patients.

Other options:

Option B: Marcus Gunn pupil, both direct and consensual light reflexes are blunted when light is shone in the affected eye. This is due to a relative afferent pupilary defect (RAPD) seen in optic nerve lesions and severe retinal diseases. It is tested by the swinging flashlight test.

Option C: Adie’s pupil is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic lesions of the oculomotor nerve. The affected pupil is larger, light reflex is sluggish, and near reflex is slow and tonic. The contralateral pupil is normal.

Option D: Wernicke’s heminanopic pupil is seen in lesions of the optic tract. Direct and consensual light reflexes are absent when light is shone on the temporal retina of the ipsilateral eye and nasal retina of the contralateral eye.

questions.text: The structure labeled as D in this image below, is developed from which of following?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as D in the given image is the cerebellum, which develops from metencephalon.

The metencephalon is a part of rhombencephalon. It is characterized by basal and alar plates and forms two components: 

(a) the cerebellum, a coordination center for posture and movement, and

(b) the pons, the pathway for nerve fibers between the spinal cord and the cerebral and cerebellar cortices.

Related Pearl: Divisions of the Developing Brain

Divisions of the Developing Brain
Forebrain vesicle/Prosencephalon

Telencephalon

  • Cerebral cortex
  • Subcortical white matter
  • Amygdala
  • Basal ganglia
  • Hippocampus
  • Olfactory bulb and tract
  • Cavities: Lateral ventricles

Diencephalon

  • Thalamus
  • Hypothalamus
  • Epithalamus
  • Subthalamus
  • Optic nerve and retina
  • Cavities: 3rd ventricle
Midbrain vesicle/Mesencephalon

Mesencephalon

  • Midbrain
  • Cavities: Cerebral Aqueduct

Hindbrain vesicle/Rhombencephalon

Metencephalon

  • Pons
  • Cerebellum 

Myelencephalon

  • Medulla oblongata

Common Cavity: 4th Ventricle

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with loin pain. Urine examination shows 120rbc/hpf. Urine microscopy revealed dysmorphic RBCs in urine. The site of origin is _______.
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario, the most likely origin is kidney.

Dysmorphic hematuria is typical of glomerulonephritis.

When the source of hematuria is the kidney, RBCs pass through the tubule and hence deformed.

The presence of eumorphic RBCs in urine indicate that the source of bleeding is below the pelvis.

Causes of hematuria

  • Renal 
  • Systemic

Renal causes can be glomerular and non-glomerular

Glomerular Non-glomerular
Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abnormal shape and size) Isomorphic RBCs seen [ normal shape and size]
Rbc casts may be present Rbc casts always absent 
Mcv is small [ <72 fl] Mcv is normal
Protein leakage is more ( >1g/day) Protein leakage is less (<1g/day)
Cause is usually medical Cause is usally surgical

questions.text: Stranger anxiety is seen at which age?
questions.solution:
Stranger anxiety is seen at 6 months.

questions.text: A boy says he hates chocolates after his parents scolded him for eating too much of it. The defence mechanism operating here is  _______________
questions.solution:
Reaction formation is the defense mechanism operating here. It converts unacceptable impulses into acceptable ones before they enter consciousness. Here, the unacceptable impulse is the boy’s fondness for chocolate, which is turned into dislike to appease his parents.

Suppression is the conscious act of avoiding unpleasant thoughts and impulses. For example, a student trying to avoid thoughts about exams.

Asceticism means giving up on life’s pleasures. The person derives gratification from giving up pleasures. For example, a rich man giving away everything he owns and going on a pilgrimage.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.
Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.
Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male who is a known Parkinson's patient is on tablet levodopa. He is to undergo an elective surgery. How many days prior to surgery should the drug be stopped?
questions.solution:
Levodopa can be continued on the day of surgery.

The following drugs can be continued on the day of surgery:

  • Antihypertensive medications: except ACE Inhibitors and ARBs
  • Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  • Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  • Thyroid medications
  • Eye drops
  • Heartburn or reflux medications
  • Narcotic medications
  • Anticonvulsant medications
  • Asthma medications
  • Steroids (oral and inhaled)
  • Statins
  • Levodopa

Related Pearl: Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

  • Antihypertensive medications: continuation of ACE Inhibitors and ARB - Controversial. According to ACC/AHA recommendations, continuation of ACE inhibitors or ARBs perioperatively is reasonable (level of evidence:B)
  • Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  • Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  • Thyroid medications
  • Eye drops
  • Heartburn or reflux medications
  • Narcotic medications
  • Anticonvulsants
  • Asthma medications
  • Steroids (oral and inhaled)
  • Statins
  • Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors : MAO inhibitors generally should be continued when two criteria are met: (1) the anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures; and (2) the psychiatrist believes temporary withdrawal of the agent will exacerbate or precipitate a depressive syndrome. 
  • Levodopa
 

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery 

  • Topical medications - discontinue on the day of surgery
  • Diuretics except thiazides - discontinue on the day of surgery
  • Oral hypoglycemic agents - discontinue on the day of surgery
  • Sildenafil - Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery
  • NSAIDs - Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery
  • Warfarin - Discontinue 4 days before surgery, except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block.
  • Short-acting Insulins except when given by a continuous pump
  • Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents
  • Aspirin should be discontinued 3 days before the surgery, in selected cases where reversal of platelet inhibition is necessary
  • MAO Inhibitors - 2 weeks prior (MAO Inhibitors are usually continued.They should be discontinued if the patient and anesthesiologist factors are not favourable to continue them)

questions.text: A 40-year-old hypothyroid female complains of heaviness and tingling in the left index and middle finger, the pain often increases in the night and is relieved on moving the hand for a while. Which of the following is not a clinical test for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests that the female is suffering from carpal tunnel syndrome.

Finkelstein test is done for de Quervain’s synovitis.

  • Hold the patient’s hand with his thumb tucked firmly unto the palm.
  • Then turn the wrist into full ulnar deviation.
  • In a positive test, this will elicit sharp pain in the  effected sheath.

Phalen’s test, Tinel’s sign, Tourniquet’s test are done for Carpal tunnel syndrome.

Related Pearl: Compression of different nerves and their syndromes

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Posterior tibial nerve

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve 
Notalgia Paresthetica Superficial sensory neuropathy in the infrascapular area (Pruritus + Dysaesthesia)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the OPD with incoordination and tremors. On examination, Abdomen is distended and shifting dullness is present. The liver is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. The ophthalmic examination shows KF ring. Which of the following is seen in the given disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture represents 'Wilson disease'. In Wilson's disease, there is inadequate excretion of copper in bile and impaired incorporation of copper into apo-ceruloplasmin. The inadequate biliary excretion is due to mutations in the ATP7B gene which encodes a copper transporting P-type ATPase.

There is no defect in production of apo-ceruloplasmin and the disease is not caused by defective intestinal absorption or renal excretion.

questions.text: Which of the following media is selective for the organism shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows Vibrio cholerae (comma-shaped, curved rod) for which thiosulfate-citrate-bile-sucrose agar is the selective medium.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple blisters on the skin. The immunofluorescence staining for IgG is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, direct immunofluorescence, and lesions show a characteristic net-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis and suprabasal acantholytic blister pointing towards the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris.

Related Pearl: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

  Pemphigus vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid
Age 30-40 years 70-80 years
Antibody Anti-desmoglein Anti-hemidesmosome
Location of target antigens Intraepidermal Subepidermal
Immuno-fluorescence Fish-net pattern Linear, shoreline pattern
Bullae Thin and fragile Deep and tense
Mouth involved Yes No
Nikolsky’s sign Positive Negative
Symptom Painful Pruritic
Severity Life threatening Resolves

questions.text: The following Intravenous pyelogram image shows ______.
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelogram (IVP) shows:

  • Ectatic distal collecting ducts contain the microcalcification, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. (option A)
  • Dilated contrast filled tubules within the renal medulla that is known as paintbrush appearance. (option B)

These findings are characteristic for medullary sponge kidney (MSK) on intravenous pyelogram.

Medullary sponge kidney represents a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to dermatology OPD with the given condition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of Melasma.

  • Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis and is manifested by hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure.
  • Hyper-melanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, chin and mandible region.
  • It is more common in women (90%) and in ages between 20-40 years.
  • Melasma is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives.
  • Melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:
    • Hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity)
    • Kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor)
    • Chemical peels
    • Kligman's triple combination- Topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream [First line]

Other Options:

  • The same facial melanosis in pregnant women is called Chloasma or mask of pregnancy. Only the terms used differ. Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Chloasma usually resolves after pregnancy.
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: A well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds. The image given below shows a malar rash.
  • Rosacea: Mainly involves the convexities of the face and presents as erythemato-telangiectatic type over the cheeks. The following image shows an image of the rash of rosacea.
